articles.headline: Yahoo to Cut About 10% of Workers
articles.snippet: Yahoo’s third-quarter income fell by 64 percent, to $54 million, and the company said it would lay off about 1,500 workers.
articles.abstract: Yahoo’s third-quarter income fell by 64 percent, to $54 million, and the company said it would lay off about 1,500 workers.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  Yahoo was hurting long before the financial crisis got everyone worried about a global recession. Now its pain has become more acute.

articles.headline: The Trouble With a Homeowner Bailout
articles.snippet: Before any of the rescue plans reaches the point of inevitability, it’s important to consider how complicated any such plan would be.
articles.abstract: Before any of the rescue plans reaches the point of inevitability, it’s important to consider how complicated any such plan would be.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the government’s ever-morphing efforts to save the financial system, the moment when the nation’s homeowners get rescued seems, finally, to be getting near.

articles.headline: On Health Plans, the Numbers Fly
articles.snippet: Senators Barack Obama and John McCain often cite rough estimates when talking about their health care plans.
articles.abstract: Senators Barack Obama and John McCain often cite rough estimates when talking about their health care plans.
articles.lead_paragraph: Economics, it is said, is the dismal science. Anyone paying close attention to the campaign debate over the economics of health care might wonder about the science part.

articles.headline: Scandal Hinders I.M.F.’s Role in Global Lending
articles.snippet: The International Monetary Fund, onetime firefighter for the global economy, is suddenly being called back into action, even as its chief stumbles on his way to the rescue.
articles.abstract: The International Monetary Fund, onetime firefighter for the global economy, is suddenly being called back into action, even as its chief stumbles on his way to the rescue.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The International Monetary Fund, onetime firefighter for the global economy, is suddenly being called back into action, even as its chief stumbles on his way to the rescue.

articles.headline: Banks Mine Data and Woo Troubled Borrowers
articles.snippet: Businesses are creating detailed profiles of the financial lives of Americans and selling that information to banks.
articles.abstract: Businesses are creating detailed profiles of the financial lives of Americans and selling that information to banks.
articles.lead_paragraph: Brenda Jerez hardly seems like the kind of person lenders would fight over.

articles.headline: McCain Fights to Keep Crucial Blue State in Play
articles.snippet: Strategists insist that Pennsylvania’s electoral votes are within reach for John McCain’s campaign.
articles.abstract: Strategists insist that Pennsylvania’s electoral votes are within reach for John McCain’s campaign.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOON TOWNSHIP, Pa.  People are scratching their heads: Why is Senator John McCain here?
articles.byline: By Elisabeth Bumiller and Jeff Zeleny

articles.headline: Dow Drops 5.7% Despite Signs of Thawing Credit
articles.snippet: Worries about the corporate sector sent stocks on Wall Street sharply lower again, with the Dow tumbling by more than 500 points.
articles.abstract: Worries about the corporate sector sent stocks on Wall Street sharply lower again, with the Dow tumbling by more than 500 points.
articles.lead_paragraph: The malaise on Wall Street simply will not lift.

articles.headline: Wal-Mart to Toughen Standards
articles.snippet: Wal-Mart plans to announce that it will require manufacturers supplying goods for its stores to adhere to stricter ethical and environmental standards.
articles.abstract: Wal-Mart plans to announce that it will require manufacturers supplying goods for its stores to adhere to stricter ethical and environmental standards.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wal-Mart plans to announce Wednesday in Beijing that it will require manufacturers supplying goods for its stores to adhere to stricter ethical and environmental standards, the latest effort by the big retailer to answer criticism of its business practices.

articles.headline: Bush Calls 20 Nations to Summit on Markets
articles.snippet: President Bush has invited the leaders of 20 nations to Washington on Nov. 15 for a summit meeting on the economy, the White House said.
articles.abstract: President Bush has invited the leaders of 20 nations to Washington on Nov. 15 for a summit meeting on the economy, the White House said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Bush will convene leaders of 20 nations in Washington on Nov. 15 for an emergency summit meeting to discuss the economic crisis, the White House said Wednesday. But the session, coming less than two weeks after the presidential election, could put Mr. Bush on a collision course with his successor.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Mark Landler
